questions.question: Find all the angles of an equilateral triangle.
questions.solution:
Given: $\triangle ABC$ is an equilateral triangle.
To find: $\angle A, \angle B, \angle C$.
Solution:
Since $\triangle ABC$ is equilateral, $AB = BC = AC$.
Since $AB = AC$, $\angle C = \angle B$ (Angles opposite to equal sides are equal).
Since $AC = BC$, $\angle B = \angle A$.
$\therefore \angle A = \angle B = \angle C$.
Let $\angle A = \angle B = \angle C = x$.
In $\triangle ABC$, $\angle A + \angle B + \angle C = 180^\circ$ (Angle sum property).
$x + x + x = 180^\circ$
$3x = 180^\circ$
$x = 60^\circ$.
Therefore, all angles of an equilateral triangle are $60^\circ$.

questions.question: The image of an object placed at a point A before a plane mirror LM is seen at the point B by an observer at D as shown in Fig. 7.12. Prove that the image is as far behind the mirror as the object is in front of the mirror.
questions.solution:
Given: Object at $A$, Image at $B$, Mirror $LM$.
To prove: Distance of $A$ from mirror = Distance of $B$ from mirror.
Proof:
Let the ray from $A$ strike the mirror at $O$ and reflect to $D$. The backward extension of $OD$ meets the normal from $A$ at $B$.
Let $AC \perp LM$ at $C$ and $BC \perp LM$ at $C$.
In $\triangle ACO$ and $\triangle BCO$:
$\angle ACO = \angle BCO = 90^\circ$.
$\angle AOC = \angle BOC$ (Angle of incidence = Angle of reflection, and vertically opposite angles).
$OC = OC$ (Common).
$\therefore \triangle ACO \cong \triangle BCO$ (by ASA congruence rule).
$\Rightarrow AC = BC$ (by CPCT).
Hence, the image is as far behind the mirror as the object is in front.

questions.question: ABC is an isosceles triangle with AB = AC and D is a point on BC such that AD ⊥ BC (Fig. 7.13). To prove that ∠BAD = ∠CAD.
questions.solution:
Given: $\triangle ABC$ with $AB = AC$ and $AD \perp BC$.
To prove: $\angle BAD = \angle CAD$.
Proof:
In right-angled triangles $\triangle ADB$ and $\triangle ADC$:
$AB = AC$ (Given, Hypotenuse)
$AD = AD$ (Common side)
$\angle ADB = \angle ADC = 90^\circ$ (Given)
$\therefore \triangle ADB \cong \triangle ADC$ (by RHS congruence rule).
$\Rightarrow \angle BAD = \angle CAD$ (by CPCT).
Hence proved.

questions.question: PQR is a triangle in which PQ = PR and S is any point on the side PQ. Through S, a line is drawn parallel to QR, intersecting PR at T. Prove that PS = PT.
questions.solution:
Given: $\triangle PQR$ with $PQ = PR$. $S$ is on $PQ$, $ST \parallel QR$ with $T$ on $PR$.
To prove: $PS = PT$.
Proof:
Since $PQ = PR$, $\angle Q = \angle R$ (Angles opposite to equal sides).
Since $ST \parallel QR$, $\angle PST = \angle Q$ (Corresponding angles) and $\angle PTS = \angle R$ (Corresponding angles).
Since $\angle Q = \angle R$, we have $\angle PST = \angle PTS$.
In $\triangle PST$, sides opposite to equal angles are equal.
$\therefore PS = PT$.
Hence proved.

questions.question: In Fig. 7.14, D is a point on side BC of ∆ABC such that AD = AC. Show that AB > AD.
questions.solution:
Given: $D$ is on $BC$ such that $AD = AC$.
To prove: $AB > AD$.
Proof:
In $\triangle ADC$, $AD = AC$ (Given).
$\therefore \angle ADC = \angle ACD$ (Angles opposite to equal sides).
Now, $\angle ADC$ is an exterior angle for $\triangle ABD$.
$\therefore \angle ADC > \angle ABD$ (Exterior angle is greater than interior opposite angle).
Since $\angle ADC = \angle ACD$, we have $\angle ACD > \angle ABD$.
In $\triangle ABC$, $\angle ACD$ is the same as $\angle C$ and $\angle ABD$ is $\angle B$.
So $\angle C > \angle B$.
Side opposite to greater angle is longer.
$\therefore AB > AC$.
Since $AC = AD$, we have $AB > AD$.
Hence proved.

questions.question: In Fig. 7.15, AD is a median of ∆ABC. Is it true that AB + BC + CA > 2 AD? Give reason for your answer.
questions.solution:
Yes, it is true.
Reason:
In $\triangle ABD$, $AB + BD > AD$ (Sum of two sides > third side).
In $\triangle ACD$, $AC + CD > AD$ (Sum of two sides > third side).
Adding both inequalities:
$(AB + BD) + (AC + CD) > AD + AD$
$AB + AC + (BD + CD) > 2AD$
$AB + AC + BC > 2AD$
Hence, $AB + BC + CA > 2AD$.

questions.question: M is a point on side BC of a triangle ABC such that AM is the bisector of ∠BAC. Is it true to say that perimeter of the triangle is greater than 2 AM? Give reason for your answer.
questions.solution:
Yes, it is true.
Reason:
In $\triangle ABM$, $AB + BM > AM$ (Triangle inequality).
In $\triangle ACM$, $AC + CM > AM$ (Triangle inequality).
Adding both:
$AB + AC + (BM + CM) > 2AM$
$AB + AC + BC > 2AM$
The perimeter of $\triangle ABC$ is $AB + BC + CA$.
Therefore, Perimeter > 2 AM.

questions.question: In Fig. 7.16, P is a point on the bisector of an angle ∠ABC. If the line through P, parallel to BA meet BC at Q, prove that BPQ is an isosceles triangle.
questions.solution:
Given: $BP$ bisects $\angle ABC$. $PQ \parallel BA$.
To prove: $\triangle BPQ$ is isosceles.
Proof:
Since $BP$ is the bisector of $\angle ABC$, $\angle ABP = \angle PBQ$.
Since $PQ \parallel BA$ and $BP$ is the transversal, $\angle ABP = \angle BPQ$ (Alternate interior angles).
From the above two equations, $\angle PBQ = \angle BPQ$.
In $\triangle BPQ$, sides opposite to equal angles are equal.
$\therefore PQ = BQ$.
Hence, $\triangle BPQ$ is an isosceles triangle.

questions.question: ABCD is a quadrilateral in which AB = BC and AD = CD. Show that BD bisects both the angles ABC and ADC.
questions.solution:
Given: Quadrilateral $ABCD$ with $AB = BC$ and $AD = CD$.
To prove: $BD$ bisects $\angle ABC$ and $\angle ADC$.
Proof:
In $\triangle ABD$ and $\triangle CBD$:
$AB = BC$ (Given)
$AD = CD$ (Given)
$BD = BD$ (Common)
$\therefore \triangle ABD \cong \triangle CBD$ (by SSS congruence rule).
$\Rightarrow \angle ABD = \angle CBD$ (by CPCT) $\Rightarrow BD$ bisects $\angle ABC$.
$\Rightarrow \angle ADB = \angle CDB$ (by CPCT) $\Rightarrow BD$ bisects $\angle ADC$.
Hence proved.

questions.question: ABC is a right triangle with AB = AC. Bisector of ∠A meets BC at D. Prove that BC = 2 AD.
questions.solution:
Given: Right $\triangle ABC$ with $\angle A = 90^\circ$ and $AB = AC$. $AD$ bisects $\angle A$.
To prove: $BC = 2AD$.
Proof:
Since $AB = AC$ and $\angle A = 90^\circ$, $\triangle ABC$ is a right isosceles triangle.
$\therefore \angle B = \angle C = 45^\circ$.
Since $AD$ bisects $\angle A$, $\angle BAD = \angle CAD = 45^\circ$.
In $\triangle ABD$, $\angle B = 45^\circ$ and $\angle BAD = 45^\circ$.
$\therefore AD = BD$ (Sides opposite to equal angles).
In $\triangle ACD$, $\angle C = 45^\circ$ and $\angle CAD = 45^\circ$.
$\therefore AD = CD$ (Sides opposite to equal angles).
Now, $BC = BD + CD = AD + AD = 2AD$.
Hence proved.

questions.question: O is a point in the interior of a square ABCD such that OAB is an equilateral triangle. Show that ∆ OCD is an isosceles triangle.
questions.solution:
Given: Square $ABCD$. $\triangle OAB$ is equilateral.
To prove: $\triangle OCD$ is isosceles.
Proof:
Since $\triangle OAB$ is equilateral, $OA = OB = AB$ and $\angle OAB = \angle OBA = 60^\circ$.
Since $ABCD$ is a square, $AB = BC = CD = DA$ and $\angle DAB = \angle CBA = 90^\circ$.
$\therefore OA = AD$ (Since $OA=AB$ and $AB=AD$).
Also, $\angle DAO = \angle DAB - \angle OAB = 90^\circ - 60^\circ = 30^\circ$.
In $\triangle OAD$, since $OA = AD$, $\angle ADO = \angle AOD = (180^\circ - 30^\circ)/2 = 75^\circ$.
Similarly, in $\triangle OBC$, $OB = BC$ and $\angle CBO = 30^\circ$.
$\therefore \angle BCO = \angle BOC = 75^\circ$.
Now, $\angle ODC = \angle ADC - \angle ADO = 90^\circ - 75^\circ = 15^\circ$.
$\angle OCD = \angle BCD - \angle BCO = 90^\circ - 75^\circ = 15^\circ$.
Since $\angle ODC = \angle OCD$, we have $OD = OC$.
$\therefore \triangle OCD$ is an isosceles triangle.

questions.question: ABC and DBC are two triangles on the same base BC such that A and D lie on the opposite sides of BC, AB = AC and DB = DC. Show that AD is the perpendicular bisector of BC.
questions.solution:
Given: $AB = AC$, $DB = DC$. $A, D$ on opposite sides of $BC$.
To prove: $AD$ is perpendicular bisector of $BC$.
Proof:
In $\triangle ABD$ and $\triangle ACD$:
$AB = AC$ (Given)
$DB = DC$ (Given)
$AD = AD$ (Common)
$\therefore \triangle ABD \cong \triangle ACD$ (by SSS congruence rule).
$\Rightarrow \angle BAD = \angle CAD$ (by CPCT).
Let $AD$ intersect $BC$ at $M$.
In $\triangle ABM$ and $\triangle ACM$:
$AB = AC$ (Given)
$\angle BAM = \angle CAM$ (Proved above)
$AM = AM$ (Common)
$\therefore \triangle ABM \cong \triangle ACM$ (by SAS congruence rule).
$\Rightarrow BM = CM$ and $\angle AMB = \angle AMC$.
Since $\angle AMB + \angle AMC = 180^\circ$ (Linear pair), $\angle AMB = 90^\circ$.
$\therefore AD$ is the perpendicular bisector of $BC$.
